Graphical abstract This report demonstrated the iso-butanol direct synthesis from syngas over varied alkali metals modified Cr/ZnO catalyst. The Cr/ZnO catalyst was prepared by a general co-precipitation method and then modified with varied alkali metals: Li, Na, K and Cs. The prepared alkali metals modified catalysts, Cr/ZnO–Li, Cr/ZnO–Na, Cr/ZnO–K and Cr/ZnO–Cs, were evaluated by the reaction of iso-butanal direct synthesis from syngas. Among these catalysts, the K modified catalyst Cr/ZnO–K exhibited excellent catalytic ability on iso-butanol synthesis. The CO conversion obtained on this Cr/ZnO–K catalyst reached up to 27.39%, with the highest iso-butanol selectivity of 15.58%. We also investigated the effect of different Li precursors, Li2CO3 and LiOH, on the catalytic performance of Cr/ZnO catalyst, and the reaction results indicated that the LiOH precursor modified catalyst Cr/ZnO–Li–OH had better catalytic performance. All the catalysts were characterized by BET, XRD, H2-TPR, SEM–EDS and TG–DTA to further disclose the function of alkali metals to Cr/ZnO catalyst in iso-butanol synthesis. We found that the reducibility of the active phase of non-stoichiometric spinel Zn x Cr2/3(1−x)O, the crucial species for iso-butanol synthesis, was significantly influenced by alkali metals modification, which consequently determined in the diverse catalytic performance of alkali metals modified catalysts for iso-butanol synthesis. Keywords Cr/ZnO catalyst Iso-butanol synthesis Syngas Non-stoicheiometric spinel Zn x Cr2/3(1−x)O 1 Introduction The synthesis of higher alcohols from syngas (a mixture of CO and H2) has roused considerable interest due to their potential application as good gasoline additives or alternative motor fuel for reducing the exhaust emission [1–2]. Among the higher alcohols, iso-butanol is one of the most important products. Iso-butanol is an important basic chemical and widely utilized for producing antioxidants, paint solvents, flavors, synthetic rubber, etc. Besides, it can also be used as additives of petroleum-derived fuels in order to enhance fuel quality [3]. In addition, it is also expected as a potential precursor for obtaining isobutene, methyl tertbutyl ether (MTBE) or isooctane (via isobutene dimerization and successive hydrogenation). Iso-butanol is a petroleum-derived product. Until now, it is obtained mainly through propylene carbonylation. But the productivity of this process cannot meet the increasing market demand in the future [4]. The catalysts for higher alcohols synthesis can be divided into two categories: one is the catalysts usually used for methanol and branched alcohols synthesis (especially iso-butanol), such as Cr/ZnO based catalysts [5–6] and Cu/ZnO based catalysts [7–8]. The other one is the catalyst for straight-chain alcohols synthesis, such as CuCo based catalysts [9–10] and MoS2 based catalysts [11–13]. The Cr/ZnO based catalysts have received most attentions due to its higher activity and selectivity for iso-butanol synthesis at high reaction temperature and pressure. Jiang [14] evaluated a Cr/ZnO–K catalyst for selective synthesis of iso-butanol from syngas by introducing a supercritical fluid into the reaction system. Roberts [15] used Cs promoted Cr/ZnO catalyst for iso-butanol synthesis in a continuous slurry reactor. In order to expand iso-butanol production, many new processes had been developed, such as bio-fermentation and coal-based iso-butanol synthesis technology [16]. Previous researchers in Germany developed a coal based methanol and iso-butanol synthesis technology, where high reaction temperature and pressure are necessary [17]. And the commonly used catalysts for this process are Cr-based catalysts with some other metals as promoter. Iso-butanol production by using the Cr/ZnO based catalysts is relatively simple, but the selectivity of iso-butanol is low. In order to promote iso-butanol selectivity, generally more harsh reaction conditions must be adopted. For the Cr/ZnO catalyst, the non-stoichiometric spinel Zn x Cr2/3(1−x)O has been generally identified as the active species for iso-butanol synthesis from syngas (Fig. 1 ) [18–20]. Although some studies on the Cr/ZnO based catalysts have been conducted, there is no report about the effect of different alkali metals modification to the Cr/ZnO catalyst in the reaction of iso-butanol direct synthesis from syngas. In this work, we prepared a Cr/ZnO catalyst by co-precipitation method. This Cr/ZnO catalyst, at higher reaction temperature, usually could realize methanol synthesis from syngas, also with few iso-butanol as by-product. In order to enhance iso-butanol selectivity, we selected some alkali metals, like Li, Na, K and Cs, as promoters to modify the pristine Cr/ZnO catalyst, by which to investigate the effect of varied alkali metals or different precursors to Cr/ZnO catalyst in the reaction of iso-butanol direct synthesis from syngas. The physical properties of the prepared alkali metals modified Cr/ZnO catalysts were further characterized by BET, XRD, H2-TPR, SEM and TG–DTA in detail to further clarify the real active phase of Cr/ZnO catalyst for iso-butanol direct synthesis from syngas. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Cr/ZnO catalyst was prepared through co-precipitation method by mixing the aqueous solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and Cr(NO3)3·9H2O (Zn:Cr=1:1 in molar) with (NH4)2CO3 as precipitant. The preparation process was performed at 60°C and pH=7.0–8.0 in a well-stirred container. The precipitate was first aged at room temperature for 24h, and then washed with deionized water until pH=7.0. After the followed drying at 120°C for 12h, the dried precipitate was further calcined at 350°C for 6h to obtain the final catalyst named Cr/ZnO. The prepared Cr/ZnO catalyst was impregnated with varied aqueous solution of Cs2CO3, K2CO3, Na2CO3, Li2CO3 or LiOH respectively. The alkali metals modified Cr/ZnO catalysts were first dried at 120°C for 12h, followed by calcination at 400°C for another 6h. The final alkali metals loading amount for each catalyst was 3wt%. The obtained catalysts, denoted as Cr/ZnO–Cs, Cr/ZnO–K, Cr/ZnO–Na, Cr/ZnO–Li and Cr/ZnO–Li–OH, were finally granulated into 30 to 40 meshes for catalytic performance evaluation. 2.2 Catalyst characterization XRD patterns were measured on a Bruker Advanced X-Ray Solutions/D8-Advance using Cu Kα radiation. The analysis was operated at 40kV and 100mA and the 2θ angles were scanned from 10° to 80°. Nitrogen adsorption measurements were carried out with a measuring instrument Micromeritics-Tristar 3000. The BET surface area, pore volume and pore size were measured. The samples were first outgassed at 200°C for 3h before each test. The H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) profiles were recorded in a fixed-bed reactor system equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. The catalyst (100mg) was pretreated at 400°C under Ar flow (40ml/min) and then cooled down to 50°C under Ar flow. Then H2–N2 (10:90) was introduced into the analysis system. H2-TPR profiles were recorded at a temperature rising rate of 5°C/ min from 50°C to 600°C. The information about the catalyst morphology was observed by Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM). After coating a platinum layer on the surface of catalyst by pretreatment machine (JEOL, JFC-1600), the morphology information of catalysts was collected by SEM (JEOL JSM-6360LV). The catalysts carbon deposition behavior was investigated by thermo gravimetric analysis (DTA/TGA-60, Shimadzu). The samples were heated at a rate of 10°C/ min from room temperature to 800°C in air flow. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation for iso-butanol synthesis The catalyst evaluation experiments were carried out in a fixed-bed tubular reactor packed with 5ml catalyst. The catalyst was diluted with quartz sand of same volume to prevent the over-heating of the catalyst due to the exothermic feature of the reaction. The flow rate of feed gas was controlled by a mass flow controller and the exit gas was measured by a wet test meter. The catalyst was reduced according to a designed temperature program from room temperature to 400°C using a gas mixture of H2–Ar (20:80) at rate of 2°C/min for 6h. After the reduction process, syngas was introduced into the reactor for reaction. The reaction conditions were as follows: H2/CO=2.3, 10MPa, GHSV=3000h−1, reaction time=6h, and reaction temperature of 400°C. The typical composition of syngas was H2 68.7 %, CO 29.5 %, CH4 0.4 % and CO2 1.4 %. Syngas and exit gas were analyzed by a gas chromatograph equipped with a column of carbon sieves and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) for the contents of H2, CH4, CO and CO2. Hydrocarbons, such as CH4 and C2H6, were analyzed using another gas chromatograph equipped with a column of GDX-403 and a flame ionization detector (FID). The composition of gas product was measured by CH4 normalization method. The alcohol products were analyzed by another gas chromatograph equipped with a column of Chromosorb 101 and a FID detector. The compositions of liquid products were identified by methanol normalization. 2.4 Calculation methods 2.4.1 Conversion calculation C CO =(F in X CO,in −Fout X CO,out)/(F in X CO,in)×100%； C CO- Conversion of CO, %; F in- The feed rate of pristine syngas, molh−1; F out- Flow of exit gas, molh−1; X CO,in-Mole fraction of CO in pristine syngas; X CO,out-Mole fraction of CO in exit gas; 2.4.2 Products selectivity calculation S i = R i , s f i , m ∑ i R i , s f i , m S i- Mass selectivity of component i, %; R i,s- Area ratio of alcohols in chromatogram; f i,m- Correction of mass; 2.4.3 The space time yield of products R i = m i t V c a t R i- The space time yield of i, g‧ml−1‧h−1;m i- The mass of alcohol, g; t- reaction time, h. 3 Result and discussions 3.1 XRD of varied alkali metals or different precursors modified Cr/ZnO catalysts Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of the different alkali metals modified Cr/ZnO catalysts: Cr/ZnO–Li, Cr/ZnO–Na, Cr/ZnO–K and Cr/ZnO–Cs. The peaks appeared at range of 30°–45° are attributed to non-stoichiometric spinel Zn x Cr2/3(1−x)O, which indicates the formation of non-stoichiometric spinel Zn x Cr2/3(1−x)O formed on all alkali metals modified Cr/ZnO catalysts successfully [21]. The peaks at about 57° and 63° are attributed to ZnO. As suggested by previous researchers, the non-stoichiometric spinel Zn x Cr2/3(1-x)O is considerably important for iso-butanol synthesis on the Cr/ZnO based catalysts. In addition, all the alkali metals modified Cr/ZnO catalysts have similar X-ray diffraction patterns, which suggests that all the catalysts crystalline structure has no obvious change and there are no other special phases appeared after modification by different alkali metals. In addition, we cannot find the peaks of alkali metals, due to the low amount of alkali metal. For the heterogeneous catalysts preparation, the catalyst precursors are very important for the catalytic performance of the prepared catalysts. In order to investigate the effect of varied catalyst precursors on the alkali metals modified Cr/ZnO catalyst performance, we also prepared another Li modified Cr/ZnO catalyst, named Cr/ZnO–Li–OH, with LiOH as the precursor instead of Li2CO3. Fig. 2 also shows the XRD patterns of the Cr/ZnO catalysts modified by different Li precursors. Although with LiOH as a different precursor, the diffraction patterns of Cr/ZnO–Li–OH catalyst are still similar to those of Cr/ZnO–Li catalyst, and the non-stoichiometric spinel Zn x Cr2/3(1−x)O has also formed successfully on this Cr/ZnO–Li–OH catalyst. Moreover, according to this XRD analysis result, we cannot find some changes on the catalyst bulk structure or the formation of new phases on the Cr/ZnO–Li–OH. 3.2 Catalysts texture characterization Table 1 gives the texture parameters of different catalysts. It can be found that the catalysts impregnated with varied alkali metals, Cr/ZnO–Li, Cr/ZnO-Na, Cr/ZnO–K and Cr/ZnO–Cs, have different textures. The BET surface area and pore volume of catalysts increases with the increase of the atomic size of alkali metals from Li to Cs. The Cr/ZnO–Cs catalyst has the largest BET surface area of and pore volume of among the tested catalysts. Table 1 also shows the texture parameters of varied Li precursors modified catalysts Cr/ZnO–Li and Cr/ZnO–Li–OH. It can be seen that the catalysts modified with different alkali metal precursors clearly show different textures parameters. The Cr/ZnO–Li–OH catalyst prepared with LiOH as precursor presents larger BET surface area, slightly enhanced pore volume and smaller pore diameter than those of the Cr/ZnO–Li catalyst. Here, the larger specific surface area of Cr/ZnO–Li–OH catalyst could afford more active sites in the followed iso-butanol synthesis reaction. 3.3 Temperature programed reduction (TPR) of the catalysts To investigate the reducibility of all catalysts, H2-TPR measurements were conducted and the results are shown in Fig. 3 . One reduction peak is found in the H2-TPR patterns for each catalyst. These reduction peaks are attributed to the reduction of non-stoichiometric spinel Zn x Cr2/3(1−x)O. Comparing with the pristine Cr/ZnO catalyst, the reduction temperature of Cr/ZnO–K and Cr/ZnO–Cs catalysts shift to lower temperature, but the other two catalysts of Cr/ZnO–Na and Cr/ZnO–Li show higher reduction temperature, as indicated in Fig. 3. After H2 adsorption, chemical compound ZnO has become free state Zn2+; the active species in the studied reaction are free state Zn2+ inside of the non-stoichiometric spinel Zn x Cr2/3(1–x)O structure. If the reducibility of non-stoichiometric spinel Zn x Cr2/3(1−x)O is higher, there will be more free state Zn2+ formed from chemical compound ZnO, as a result the catalyst activity will be better [22,23]. Cr/ZnO–Li catalyst has the highest reduction temperature of 390°C among the tested catalysts. Although modified by K, the Cr/ZnO–K catalyst exhibits the lowest reduction temperature of 300°C that is even lower than the reduction temperature of 320°C for the Cr/ZnO–Cs catalyst. Alkali metal is good electron promoter. It can transfer charge to the active phase and increase the charge density. Consequently, the reducibility of alkali metal modified Cr/ZnO catalysts are changed, and thus the catalysts activity for iso-butanol synthesis will be altered. However, extremely strong or weak electron releasing ability of alkali metal candidate cannot promote the catalyst reducibility, as well as catalytic activity [24]. Here, the H2-TPR results indicate that the non-stoichiometric spinel Zn x Cr2/3(1−x)O in Cr/ZnO–K catalyst is easier to be reduced, compared with that in other alkali metals modified Cr/ZnO catalysts. The good reducibility of Cr/ZnO–K catalyst will promote its catalytic performance in the followed iso-butanol synthesis. In addition, reduction peaks area has a tendency: Cr/ZnO–Li≈Cr/ZnO–Na<Cr/ZnO–K≈Cr/ZnO–Cs, which also indicates that the reduction of non-stoichiometric spinel Zn x Cr2/3(1−x)O in different catalysts is affected clearly by varied alkali metals. We also employed H2-TPR to investigate the reducibility of the Cr/ZnO–Li–OH catalyst that was prepared with LiOH as precursor, and the measurement result is shown in Fig. 3. Similar to that of Cr/ZnO–Li catalyst, there is only one major reduction peak for this Cr/ZnO–Li–OH catalyst. The reduction peak is also associated with the reduction of non-stoichiometric spinel Zn x Cr2/3(1−x)O. The reduction temperature of this Cr/ZnO–Li–OH catalyst shifts to lower temperature of 330°C, lower than that of Cr/ZnO–Li catalyst prepared with Li2CO3 as precursor. The latter catalyst gives higher reduction temperature of 390°C. The reduction peak area of Cr/ZnO–Li–OH catalyst, however, is smaller than that of Cr/ZnO–Li catalyst, indicating less amount of non-stoichiometric spinel Zn x Cr2/3(1−x)O on this catalyst. The H2-TPR analysis results indicate that Cr/ZnO–Li–OH is easier to be reduced than Cr/ZnO–Li catalyst, which will favor the catalytic activity of Cr/ZnO–Li–OH catalyst in the followed iso-butanol synthesis reaction. 3.4 SEM and EDS analysis on the alkali metals modified catalysts SEM is used to analyze the morphology of the alkali metals modified catalysts, and the analysis results are shown in Fig. 4 . It is found that all the catalysts have different morphology. For Cr/ZnO–Li, Cr/ZnO–Li–OH and Cr/ZnO–Na catalysts in Fig. 4b–d, the catalyst particles aggregate clearly, and the degree of particle aggregation on Cr/ZnO–Li catalyst is higher than that of Cr/ZnO–Na catalyst. The catalysts particles of Cr/ZnO–K, as shown in Fig. 4e, are the smallest among the analyzed catalysts. Although the catalysts particles of Cr/ZnO-Cs catalyst in Fig. 4f are larger than that of Cr/ZnO–K catalyst, there is no obvious particle aggregation [25]. In combination with the analysis results obtained from H2-TPR and BET, it can be concluded that catalyst particle aggregation on Cr/ZnO–Li and Cr/ZnO–Na catalysts possibly leads to their poor reducibility and lower BET surface areas. The modification of pristine Cr/ZnO catalyst by alkali metals probably alters the distribution of active components of Cr and Zn. Therefore, we also employed the line EDS analysis to measure element of composition of these alkali metals modified Cr/ZnO catalysts: Cr/ZnO–Li, Cr/ZnO–Na, Cr/ZnO–K and Cr/ZnO–Cs, as well as Cr/ZnO. Fig. 5 compares the random EDS line scanning results along the yellow line marked on the related SEM images of different alkali metals modified catalysts. As shown by the EDS line analysis results in Fig. 5, all the catalysts, along with the scanning line, have the molar ratio of Cr to Zn at about 1 that is same to the catalyst preparation recipe. This result suggests that, although with the modification by different alkali metals, the active phases in the Cr/ZnO–Li, Cr/ZnO–Na, Cr/ZnO–K and Cr/ZnO–Cs catalysts distribute homogeneously without any change or newly formed phases. 3.5 TG–DTA analysis of catalyst In order to identify the coke possibly formed during the reaction, we employed TG/DTA to further analysis the fresh and spent Cr/ZnO–K catalyst. The analysis results are shown in the Fig. 6 . For the fresh catalyst, in the range of 30–800°C, the TG curve exhibits a slowly decreased tendency, and the related DTA curve shows exothermic peaks. In the range of 100–350°C, the physically adsorbed water and the chemical crystal water in catalyst decompose along with the increase of temperature. In the range of 350–800°C, there is no obvious decline for TG curve, which indicates that no chemicals decomposition or phase transfer happened on the fresh catalyst. And a small quantity of weight loss should be attributed to the desorption of few hydroxyl groups on catalyst [26]. The spent catalyst shows similar TG curve and DTA profile to that of fresh catalyst, except for a strong exothermic peak in 200–300°C. The strong exothermic peak appeares here should be ascribed to the decomposition of CHx species on the catalyst surface. Thus, the characterization results of TG/DTA suggests that no coke deposition on the Cr/ZnO–K catalyst after reaction. As well known, the Cr/ZnO based catalysts, as one of the high temperature methanol synthesis catalysts, have many advantages such as long life time in reaction. The TG/DTA analysis of the Cr/ZnO–K catalyst also proved this conclusion.. 3.6 Catalyst performance evaluation for iso-butanol direct synthesis from syngas These alkali metals modified catalysts, Cr/ZnO–Li, Cr/ZnO–Na, Cr/ZnO–K and Cr/ZnO–Cs were tested, for the direct synthesis of iso-butanol from syngas. The pure Cr/ZnO catalyst, as the reference catalyst, had also been tested under the same reaction conditions. The reaction results are compared in Table 2 . This pure Cr/ZnO catalyst shows good CO conversion of 26.71% and iso-butanol selectivity of 9.27%. Among the modified catalysts, the Li2CO3 precursor modified catalyst Cr/ZnO–Li shows the lowest CO conversion of 11.81% and iso-butanol selectivity of 5.63 %. It shows lower catalytic performance than the original Cr/ZnO. The Na and K modified catalysts Cr/ZnO–Na, Cr/ZnO–K exhibit similar CO conversion of 28.62% and 27.39% respectively, higher than that of Cr/ZnO catalyst. The Cr/ZnO–Cs catalyst presents the highest catalytic activity with the CO conversion reaching up to 31.93 %. The pristine Cr/ZnO catalyst is a well-known catalyst usually used for methanol synthesis under higher reaction temperature, therefore the major product as given in Table 2 for all alkali metals modified catalysts is methanol, accompanying with few other alcohols like normal propanol (n-PrOH), normal butanol (n-BuOH), iso-butanol (i-BuOH), etc. As proved by previous researchers, the non-stoichiometric spinel Zn x Cr2/3(1−x)O phase in Cr/ZnO catalyst can obviously affect the catalysts performance especially on iso-butanol selectivity [27]. XRD analysis results in Fig. 2 has indicated that, although with the modification by alkali metals, the active phase on Cr/ZnO–Li, Cr/ZnO–Na, Cr/ZnO–K and Cr/ZnO–Cs catalysts is the non-stoichiometric spinel Zn x Cr2/3(1−x)O similar to that of pristine Cr/ZnO catalyst. However, with the modification by varied alkali metals on the Cr/ZnO catalyst, the alcohols distributions obtained by these catalysts have changed clearly, especially that for iso-butanol selectivity. As in Table 2, The Cr/ZnO–K shows the highest iso-butanol selectivity of 15.58%, at the same time depressing the formation of CO2 completely. Alkali metals, as additives, can effectively promote the growth of carbon chain in reaction, by which to change the alcohols distribution. The alkali metals have no effect on alcohols yield, but influence the alcohols distribution obviously. It has been proved that the alkali metals are not the active phase of catalyst for alcohols formation. However it can change the distribution of alcohols by affecting the active component on catalyst. Alkali metals are also good electronic assistant to transfer the charge to the active phase of non-stoichiometric spinel Zn x Cr2/3(1−x)O, increasing the charge density, so as to improve the catalytic performance. Appropriate electronic release ability of alkali metals can cause more active component on the catalyst, finally to achieve better catalytic performance for iso-butanol formation [28]. This result demonstrates that the alkali metals modification can affect the pristine Cr/ZnO catalyst performance on iso-butanol synthesis, possibly by affecting the reducibility or space electronic composition of active phases. The further studies on the detailed reaction mechanism are now in progress. Table 2 also compares the catalytic performance of the two different alkali metal precursors modified catalysts: Cr/ZnO–Li and Cr/ZnO–Li–OH. The CO conversion of this Cr/ZnO–Li–OH catalyst reaches up to 22.62% twice higher than that of Cr/ZnO–Li catalyst with LiCO3 as precursor. Although the similar methanol selectivity is obtained by these two catalysts, varied high alcohols distribution, especially on iso-butanol selectivity, is achieved. The alcohols yield and iso-butanol selectivity on the Cr/ZnO–Li–OH catalyst are 0.05gml−1 h−1 and 7.07%, respectively, which are rather higher than those for the Cr/ZnO–Li catalyst. Therefore, it is noted that different alkali metal precursors can obviously affect the catalysts performance, as well as the iso-butanol selectivity. Both of Cr/ZnO–Li and Cr/ZnO–Li–OH catalysts have the same active phase of non-stoichiometric spinel Zn x Cr2/3(1−x)O, as indicated by their XRD analysis in Fig. 2. However, the amount of the related active phase on both catalysts is different, which has been proved by their H2-TPR analysis given in Fig. 3. The Cr/ZnO–Li–OH catalyst has less active phase, which is more easily being reduced than that of Cr/ZnO–Li catalyst. The higher reducibility of Cr/ZnO–Li–OH catalyst, due to the utilization of LiOH precursor, probably contributes to its higher catalyst activity and the enhanced iso-butanol selectivity. In addition, the amount of non-dissociative CO on catalyst significantly affects the catalyst performance for the studied reaction, and the amount of non-dissociative CO is decided by the alkaline active sites of different alkali metals modified catalysts. If more non-dissociative CO is created by catalyst, as a result the ability of H2 adsorption is weaken, and then more CO2 will be produced; otherwise, the processing of alcohol chain growth will be more difficult. These factors lead to the different results on iso-butanol selectivity and CO2 selectivity of varied alkali metals modified catalyst in reaction [28,29]. 4 Conclusions In this report, on the basis of Cr/ZnO catalyst, we employed four alkali metals (Na, K, Cs and Li) and two different alkali metal precursors to modify the Cr/ZnO catalyst, and then investigated the catalytic activity and performance of modified catalysts for iso-butanol direct synthesis from syngas. Three alkali metals of Na, K and Cs, rather than Li, could obviously improve the iso-butanol selectivity, as well as the catalyst activity as CO conversion. Among the tested catalysts, the K modified catalyst Cr/ZnO–K displayed a better CO conversion of 27.39% and the highest iso-butanol selectivity of 15.58%. The Cr/ZnO–Li–OH catalyst with LiOH as precursor exhibited higher catalyst activity and iso-butanol selectivity than the Cr/ZnO–Li catalyst modified with Li2CO3 as precursor. The catalyst characterization demonstrated that the non-stoichimetric spinel of Zn x Cr2/3(1−x)O in Cr/ZnO catalyst should be the active phase for iso-butanol synthesis from syngas. The suitable alkali metals modification to the Cr/ZnO catalyst promoted the catalyst reducibility, boosting the activation of CO and H2 under the used reaction conditions, as well as enhancing catalyst performance on both syngas conversion and iso-butanol synthesis. The clarified studies of alkali metals modification to Cr/ZnO catalyst provide new insight into the reaction of iso-butanol direct synthesis from syngas. coredata.dc:description: This report demonstrated the iso-butanol direct synthesis from syngas over varied alkali metals modified Cr/ZnO catalyst. The Cr/ZnO catalyst was prepared by a general co-precipitation method and then modified with varied alkali metals: Li, Na, K and Cs. The prepared alkali metals modified catalysts, Cr/ZnO–Li, Cr/ZnO–Na, Cr/ZnO–K and Cr/ZnO–Cs, were evaluated by the reaction of iso-butanal direct synthesis from syngas. Among these catalysts, the K modified catalyst Cr/ZnO–K exhibited excellent catalytic ability on iso-butanol synthesis. The CO conversion obtained on this Cr/ZnO–K catalyst reached up to 27.39%, with the highest iso-butanol selectivity of 15.58%. We also investigated the effect of different Li precursors, Li2CO3 and LiOH, on the catalytic performance of Cr/ZnO catalyst, and the reaction results indicated that the LiOH precursor modified catalyst Cr/ZnO–Li–OH had better catalytic performance. All the catalysts were characterized by BET, XRD, H2-TPR, SEM–EDS and TG–DTA to further disclose the function of alkali metals to Cr/ZnO catalyst in iso-butanol synthesis. We found that the reducibility of the active phase of non-stoichiometric spinel Zn x Cr2/3(1−x)O, the crucial species for iso-butanol synthesis, was significantly influenced by alkali metals modification, which consequently determined in the diverse catalytic performance of alkali metals modified catalysts for iso-butanol synthesis.
coredata.dc:title: Iso-butanol direct synthesis from syngas over the alkali metals modified Cr/ZnO catalysts
